name: Network Disconnect
description: The information system terminates a network connection at the end of a session or after [Assignment: organization-defined time period] of inactivity.
supplemental_guidance: The organization applies this control within the context of risk management that considers specific mission or operational requirements.

attack_techniques.name: Application Layer Protocol
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Automatic network disconnection after session timeouts terminates adversary command-and-control channels that rely on persistent application-layer protocol connections.

attack_techniques.name: Web Protocols
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Network disconnect after session timeout terminates HTTP/HTTPS-based C2 channels, forcing adversaries to re-establish web protocol connections and increasing detection opportunities at reconnection.

attack_techniques.name: File Transfer Protocols
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Automatic disconnection of idle file transfer protocol sessions terminates adversary FTP/SFTP-based data exfiltration channels, requiring new session establishment for continued data transfer.

attack_techniques.name: Mail Protocols
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Network disconnect on idle mail protocol sessions terminates SMTP/IMAP-based C2 and exfiltration channels, preventing adversaries from maintaining persistent email protocol connections for covert communication.

attack_techniques.name: DNS
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Automatic disconnection of persistent DNS connections terminates DNS-based C2 tunnels, forcing adversaries to re-establish DNS communication channels and generating detectable reconnection patterns.
